document.docAuthor: Bragagnolo, Cibele, Hara, Marcos R. & Pinto-Da-Rocha, Ricardo
document.docOrigin: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society 173 (2)
document.docTitle: Gerdesius mapinguari Bragagnolo & Hara & Pinto-Da-Rocha 2015, SP. NOV.
document.masterDocTitle: A new family of Gonyleptoidea from South America (Opiliones, Laniatores)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new family of Gonyleptoidea from South America (Opiliones, Laniatores)
Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society

subSubSection.paragraph: Mapinguari is an Amazonian mythological creature. This being is a tall mammal of approximately 2.0– 2.5 m , body entirely covered with long hair, bullet- proof skin, claws, and a huge mouth (from the head to the belly). It has a strong and bad odoriferous scent, like harvestmen.

BRAZIL . Amazonas : Manaus ( Reserva do Km 54),
IX.2009
, G. Machado leg., ♂ holotype ( MZSP 59906 )
.

Gerdesius mapinguari
sp. nov. differs from other members of the genus by: scutal area IV with a row of slightly enlarged tubercles; free tergite I with a lateral spine on each side and anal operculum with a median short (as long as free tergite III) apophysis.
Venter. Coxa I–IV, genital area and free sternites densely tuberculate.

Chelicera. Normal sized. Segment I with four enlarged, pointed tubercles on posterior margin of bulla (retrolateral largest), one subapical tubercle on prolateral face; segments II and III each with four teeth.
Coloration. Background colour orange–brown, slightly clear brown on legs I–III. Tubercles of dorsal scutum, coxa IV, free tergites and sternites blackish. Pedipalps yellowish brown.
